item.title: 2020#37 Readings of the Week
item.description: First edition of the New Year. As eclectic as usual, I hope. The audio-based monitoring of servers and the weird uses of the GPT-2 neural network could be two highlights.

item.title: 2019#36 Readings of the Week
item.description: On time this week. Nothing remarkable: I’m winding down a bit my reading (both articles and books) in preparation for the yearly review and having some cooldown period.

item.title: A (section) of a map of the data engineering space
item.description: The map and problem described here were part of my presentation Mapping as a tool for thought, and mentioned in my interview with John Grant and Ben Mosior (to appear sometime soon in the Wardley Maps community youtube channel). I’m looking for ideas on how to make this map easier to understand and useful, so I posted it to the Wardley Maps Community forums requesting comments.

item.title: 2019#4 Readings of the week
item.description: Sorry for the delay, Sunday was my birthday (also, Elmo’s, and The Day The Music Died as well) and I spent the day without access to a computer.

item.title: 2019#3 Readings of the week
item.description: Software/data engineering, history, formal systems. Expect a similar wide range in the future as well. You can check all weekly readings by checking the tag here . You can also get these as a weekly newsletter by subscribing here.

item.title: 2018: Year in Review
item.description: The year has ended, what has been going on?

item.title: Notifications from Spark on an Apple Watch (via IFTTT)
item.description: This week I have been working a lot with a relatively large dataset on a Spark shell. It was a graph with 1 billion nodes and 2 billion edges that I wanted to analyse with GraphFrames (the successor of GraphX on Spark).

item.title: Scala eXchange 2017
item.description: Almost two months ago (time sure flies) I attended for the second time the conference Scala eXchange, one of the largest Scala conferences in the world, and which happens to be 1 tube stop from the office you can find me from time to time in London.

item.title: 2017: Year in Review
item.description: I am trying to make these posts a tradition (even if a few days late). I thought 2016 had been a really weird and fun year, but 2017 has beaten it easily. And I only hope 2018 will be even better in every way. For the record, when I say we, it means Laia and me unless explicitly changed.
